body: December of 2017, BTC reached 19k, and then it crashed all the way down to 4k. 2019, it reached 10k, that's when I buy in. When it went to 13k, I sold and thought it would go back down to 10k. Hold until you can retire, and you will have one less problem to worry about(hopefully that problem is money)

author: Fulvio55
body: No. Just NO.  This is the problem with market cap. People look at whatâ€™s actually an imaginary number and think that money changed hands, when nothing could be further from the truth.  In actual fact, itâ€™s the trades which set the prices. So if two people trade one doge for one dollar, then $1 becomes the spot price which is then multiplied by the number of coins issued to give a market cap. But it only involved a single dollar, not billions.  Of course spot prices only hold until the very next trade, so this isnâ€™t going to happen in reality. But it can in theory, and has on a few occasions like the six pump and dumps weâ€™ve had.  Regardless, half of all coins have been lost, and most of the rest never move. So the coins churning around are really a tiny subset of all doge.

author: MrKillerKiller_
body: Price is all that matters. Inflating 5 billion a year means diluting your bagâ€¦if you hold for a year. Know this and consider yourself learned.

author: Fulvio55
body: Except youâ€™re wrong.  Doge prices mostly remain steady. Itâ€™s what makes us a superior currency to the more volatile alternatives. And yet, supply increases every minute. Which means the theoretical market cap increases without diluting anything.  Itâ€™s called baking a bigger cake rather than slicing it thinner.  And again, anyone with any sense is trading constantly and really doesnâ€™t care what prices do.

It would have disappeared in early 2015.  As I said, do some research, and stop spreading made-up bullshit.
